# Sprint Planning

## Overview

This skill helps teams execute effective sprint planning sessions by guiding backlog refinement, user story creation, sprint goal definition, capacity planning, and work estimation. It combines agile best practices with practical templates to ensure productive sprints.

## Activation

This skill activates when you need to:
- Plan an upcoming sprint
- Refine the product backlog
- Create or improve user stories
- Define sprint goals and success criteria
- Estimate team capacity and velocity
- Prioritize work items
- Run sprint planning ceremonies

## Instructions

When activated, this skill will:

1. **Backlog Refinement**
   - Review and prioritize backlog items
   - Identify dependencies and blockers
   - Ensure stories are ready for sprint planning
   - Split large stories into manageable chunks

2. **User Story Creation**
   - Guide proper user story format
   - Define acceptance criteria
   - Add technical notes and constraints
   - Ensure stories follow INVEST principles

3. **Sprint Goal Definition**
   - Craft clear, measurable sprint goals
   - Align goals with product roadmap
   - Ensure team understanding and buy-in

4. **Capacity Planning**
   - Calculate available team capacity
   - Account for PTO, holidays, meetings
   - Consider team velocity trends
   - Plan sustainable workload

5. **Estimation & Commitment**
   - Facilitate estimation sessions
   - Use planning poker or other techniques
   - Determine sprint commitment
   - Identify risks and mitigation strategies

## Examples

### Example 1: E-commerce Sprint Planning

**Context**: Planning Sprint 24 for an e-commerce platform

**Sprint Goal**: "Enable customers to save items for later purchase and manage their wishlist"

**User Stories**:

```markdown
# US-156 - Add to Wishlist

As a registered customer
I want to add items to my wishlist
So that I can save products I'm interested in for future purchase

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] Given I'm viewing a product, when I click "Add to Wishlist", then the item is saved to my wishlist
- [ ] Given an item is in my wishlist, when I view the product, then the heart icon shows filled state
- [ ] Given I'm not logged in, when I click "Add to Wishlist", then I'm prompted to log in
- [ ] Given I add an item to wishlist, when the item goes on sale, then I receive a notification

Technical Notes:
- Create wishlist table: user_id, product_id, added_at, notify_on_sale
- Add GraphQL mutation: addToWishlist(productId: ID!)
- Implement Redis cache for wishlist counts
- Set up notification service integration

Estimation: 5 points
```

```markdown
# US-157 - Wishlist Management Page

As a registered customer
I want to view and manage all items in my wishlist
So that I can review saved items and add them to cart when ready

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] Given I have wishlist items, when I navigate to /wishlist, then I see all saved items with images, titles, and current prices
- [ ] Given I'm viewing my wishlist, when I click "Add to Cart" on an item, then it's added to my shopping cart
- [ ] Given I'm viewing my wishlist, when I click remove, then the item is removed from my wishlist
- [ ] Given an item is out of stock, when I view my wishlist, then it's marked as unavailable
- [ ] Given I have 50+ items, when I view my wishlist, then items are paginated (20 per page)

Technical Notes:
- Create wishlist page component with React
- Implement infinite scroll/pagination
- Add product availability check
- Update product price in real-time

Estimation: 8 points
```

**Capacity Planning**:
- Team: 5 developers
- Sprint: 10 days
- PTO: 2 days (Developer A)
- Average velocity: 42 points
- Sprint commitment: 40 points (6 stories)

### Example 2: Mobile App Sprint Planning

**Sprint Goal**: "Implement offline mode for core app features"

**Key Stories**:

```markdown
# US-201 - Offline Data Sync

As a mobile app user
I want my data to sync when I regain connectivity
So that I don't lose work done while offline

Acceptance Criteria:
- [ ] Given I'm offline, when I create/edit content, then changes are queued locally
- [ ] Given I have pending changes, when I regain connectivity, then changes sync automatically
- [ ] Given sync is in progress, when I view the app, then I see sync status indicator
- [ ] Given there's a sync conflict, when sync occurs, then I'm prompted to resolve it

Technical Notes:
- Implement SQLite local database
- Create sync queue with retry logic
- Add conflict resolution strategy (last-write-wins or manual)
- Store sync state in Redux

Dependencies:
- Requires: US-198 (Local database setup)
- Blocks: US-203 (Offline image caching)

Estimation: 13 points
Priority: Critical
```

**Risk Assessment**:
1. **Risk**: Sync conflicts complex to handle
   **Mitigation**: Start with simple last-write-wins, plan user resolution for next sprint

2. **Risk**: Developer A out 2 days (backend expert)
   **Mitigation**: Pair Developer B with Developer A before PTO, document API changes

### Example 3: SaaS Platform Sprint Planning

**Sprint Goal**: "Launch role-based access control for enterprise customers"

**Planning Poker Session**:

```markdown
Story: US-301 - Role Management UI

Discussion:
- Need to create roles CRUD interface
- Permission matrix could be complex
- Similar to what we built in admin panel

Estimates:
- Dev A: 5 points (familiar with admin UI patterns)
- Dev B: 8 points (concerned about permission complexity)
- Dev C: 5 points (agrees with Dev A)
- Dev D: 8 points (thinks testing will take time)

Consensus Discussion:
- Agree permission matrix is most complex part
- Can reuse admin panel components
- Testing needs special attention

Final Estimate: 5 points
(Team agrees 8 was accounting for permission logic, which is separate story US-302)
```

**Sprint Commitment**:

```markdown
Total Capacity: 38 points

Committed Stories:
1. US-301 - Role Management UI (5 pts) ✓
2. US-302 - Permission System Backend (8 pts) ✓
3. US-303 - Role Assignment (5 pts) ✓
4. US-304 - Audit Logging (5 pts) ✓
5. US-305 - Role Migration Tool (3 pts) ✓
6. US-306 - Documentation (3 pts) ✓
7. BUG-89 - Fix export timeout (3 pts) ✓
8. TECH-45 - Upgrade auth library (5 pts) ✓

Total: 37 points
Buffer: 1 point (3%)
Confidence: High
```

### Example 5: Sprint Goals Evolution

```markdown
# Sprint Goal Examples

## Good Sprint Goals

### Goal 1: User-Centric
"Enable customers to complete checkout in under 60 seconds"
- Measurable: checkout time < 60s
- Valuable: improves conversion rate
- Focused: clear scope

### Goal 2: Technical + Business Value
"Migrate user authentication to OAuth 2.0 while maintaining 99.9% uptime"
- Technical objective: OAuth migration
- Business constraint: no downtime
- Measurable: uptime metrics

### Goal 3: Feature Launch
"Launch MVP of team collaboration features for beta customers"
- Clear deliverable: MVP launch
- Target audience: beta customers
- Scope: collaboration features

## Poor Sprint Goals (and How to Fix)

### Too Vague
❌ "Work on the admin panel"
✓ "Complete user management features in admin panel (create, edit, delete, roles)"

### Too Broad
❌ "Improve application performance"
✓ "Reduce API response time to <200ms for product search"

### Just a List
❌ "Complete US-123, US-124, US-125, US-126"
✓ "Enable customers to track order status in real-time"

### No Clear Value
❌ "Refactor the codebase"
✓ "Refactor checkout service to enable A/B testing for conversion optimization"
```

## Best Practices

1. **INVEST in User Stories**
   - **I**ndependent: Stories can be developed in any order
   - **N**egotiable: Details can be discussed
   - **V**aluable: Delivers value to users/business
   - **E**stimable: Team can estimate effort
   - **S**mall: Can be completed in one sprint
   - **T**estable: Clear acceptance criteria

2. **Sprint Planning Tips**
   - Time-box the meeting (2 hours per week of sprint)
   - Come prepared with refined backlog
   - Focus on the "what" and "why", not just "how"
   - Ensure whole team participates in estimation
   - Don't overcommit - leave 10-20% buffer

3. **Capacity Planning**
   - Track actual vs. estimated capacity
   - Account for support/maintenance work
   - Consider team member skills and availability
   - Plan for sustainable pace

4. **Effective Estimation**
   - Use relative sizing (story points)
   - Base estimates on similar past work
   - Involve the whole team
   - Re-estimate if you learn something new

5. **Sprint Goal Guidelines**
   - One clear goal per sprint
   - Should be achievable and measurable
   - Aligned with product roadmap
   - Communicated to stakeholders

## Common Pitfalls

- **Overcommitment**: Taking on too much work leads to incomplete sprints
- **Lack of Definition of Ready**: Starting work on unclear stories wastes time
- **Skipping Refinement**: Poor preparation leads to long planning meetings
- **Ignoring Dependencies**: Not identifying blockers early causes delays
- **No Sprint Goal**: Team loses focus without a unifying objective
- **Estimation Bias**: Individual estimates vs. team consensus

## Tools & Techniques

- **Planning Poker**: Gamified estimation using Fibonacci sequence
- **T-Shirt Sizing**: Quick estimation using S/M/L/XL
- **Dot Voting**: Team prioritizes stories democratically
- **MoSCoW Method**: Must have, Should have, Could have, Won't have
- **Story Mapping**: Visualize user journey and feature set
